title: The Russian Billionaire Selling Putin's War to the Public
description: Yuri Kovalchuk, with vast holdings in banking and media, is helping his longtime friend Vladimir Putin tighten the Kremlin’s grip on the internet.

title: Ukraine Clamps Down on Orthodox Church Linked to Moscow
description: Ukraine’s government moved to curb the activities of the Orthodox Christian denomination historically linked to Moscow, aiming to cut off the most important remaining source of Russian cultural and religious influence in the country.

title: China Turns to Well-Worn Playbook to Keep Protesters Off Streets
description: Authorities move to address the demands of protesters by signaling an easing of strict Covid policies and by deploying police to the sites of protests and hunting down activists.

title: Russia Rejects Biden's Terms for Talks on Ukraine
description: The Kremlin rejected President Biden’s conditions for negotiations over Ukraine with Russian President Vladimir Putin, insisting that Moscow’s military campaign in the country would continue.

title: EU, G-7 Wait on Poland to Advance Russian Oil-Price Cap
description: The European Union and the Group of Seven advanced economies are awaiting word on whether Poland will agree to a $60-a-barrel price cap on Russian oil that is supposed to take effect Monday.

title: Canada Pushes Canadian Content, Irking Big Tech
description: The proposal would require digital platforms to rework algorithms to feature content from Canadian artists.

title: European Frustration Over U.S. Subsidies Mounts Ahead of Key Meeting
description: Rising tensions over the “Buy American” provisions attached to a package of climate-related subsidies threatens to spoil the mood at Monday’s high-level U.S.-European Union meeting.

title: Ukraine Hunts the World for Parts to Fix Energy Grid
description: The constant repairs to damage caused by Russian strikes have led to a critical shortage of everything from transformers to cables.

title: Chinese Solar Manufacturers Dodged U.S. Tariffs
description: The preliminary Commerce Department findings, expected on Friday, are likely to accelerate importers’ race to find other sources.
